sn4.19:4.2: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dharma talk about extinguishment.
sn4.19:4.3: And those mendicants were paying attention, focusing, concentrating, and listening well.
sn4.19:5.2: “The ascetic Gotama is giving a Dharma talk about extinguishment … and the mendicants are listening well.
sn4.19:5.3: Why don’t I go and pull the wool over their eyes?”
sn4.19:5.4: Then Māra the Wicked manifested in the form of a farmer carrying a large plough on his shoulder. He held a long goad, his hair was messy, he was clad in hemp, and his feet were muddy.
sn4.19:5.5: He went up to the Buddha and said to him:
sn4.19:5.6: “So, ascetic, did you happen to see any oxen?”
sn4.19:5.7: “But what have you to do with oxen, Wicked One?”
sn4.19:5.8: “Mine alone, ascetic, is the eye, mine are sights, mine is the field of eye contact consciousness.
sn4.19:5.9: Where can you escape me, ascetic?
sn4.19:5.14: mind, mine are phenomena, mine is the field of mind contact consciousness.
sn4.19:5.15: Where can you escape me, ascetic?”
sn4.19:6.1: “Yours alone, ascetic, is the eye, yours are sights, yours is the field of eye contact consciousness.
sn4.19:6.2: Where there is no eye, no sights, no eye contact consciousness—you have no place there, Wicked One!
sn4.19:6.9: mind, yours are phenomena, yours is the field of mind contact consciousness.
sn4.19:6.10: Where there is no mind, no phenomena, no mind contact consciousness—you have no place there, Wicked One!”
sn4.19:8.1: “The things they speak of aren’t mine;
sn4.19:8.2: I’m not someone who speaks like that.
sn4.19:8.4: you won’t even see my path.”
